source.6686d4a9:
As you can see above, several readability scores have been computed by Textstatistic. Each of these scores relies on a different formula that scores the ease with which a given text can be read. Different forumula are appropriate for different contexts; you will need to use your discretion for which score is most appropriate for your corpus.

For example, consider the **Gunning Fog Score**: 

Named after Robert Gunning, the Gunning Fog Score was originally developed in the early 1940s to reduce “fog” in newspapers and business writing. Gunning was a private consultant for newspapers and businesses; his objective was to help his clients produce more clear, accesible writing that could reach wider audiences. This was the logic underlying the Fog Index, which is considered to be one of the most reliable and simplest forumula to apply:
       
> Fog Index = 0.4 * ((average sentence length) + (percentage of Hard Words))
>
> Where *Hard Words* = words with more than two syllables

But there are many different scores designed for various applications. A helpful explainer of alternative metrics can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Readability#Popular_readability_formulas

## Textstat

Textstat is a Python package that calculates statistics from texts to determine their readability, complexity and school grade level.

Textstat has many readability scores already built in.

### Flesch-Kincaid Grade 

Used extensively in the education field, the "Flesch–Kincaid Grade Level Formula" presents a U.S. grade level score, making it easier for teachers, parents, librarians, and others to judge the readability level of various books and texts. It can also mean the number of years of education generally required to understand this text, relevant when the formula results in a number greater than 10. 

For example, a score of 9.3 means that a ninth grader would be able to read the document.

### Dale-Chall Readability socre

Provides a numeric gauge of the comprehension difficulty that readers come upon when reading a text. It uses a list of 3000 words that groups of fourth-grade American students could reliably understand, considering any word not on that list to be difficult.

# Readability

Readability is the ease with which a reader can understand written text. In natural language, readability depends on its content (i.e. the complexity of vocabulary and syntax). Our focus in readability analysis is the words themselves -- in particular, how they are arranged into more or less comprehensible sentences and paragraphs.

Think about what good writing looks like. Good writing is intended to communicate information. If a piece of writing fails to convey that information, it is likely because it was not written in a clear, straightfoward fashion. The types of words used and the structure of grammar are thus crucial towards creating a more or less readable document. This is the intuition behind readability metrics - that good writing follows a consistent structure, one that can be quantified.

Below, we will explore various readability formulae used in NLP. Readability Scores were originally designed to assist writers in improving their content  to make it understandable for larger audiences.

## Textastistic

Let's start with the Textastic software from Erin Hengel. She developed this code to investigate whether academic journals demand clearer, more concise writing from women than they do men.

http://www.erinhengel.com/software/textatistic/
